document.docAuthor: Quicke, Donald L. J., Smith, M. Alex, Achterberg, Cornelis van, Miller, Scott E. & Hrcek, Jan
document.docTitle: Vojtechirogas Quicke & van Achterberg 2012, gen. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new genus and three new species of parasitoid wasp from Papua New Guinea and redescription of Trigonophatnus Cameron (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Rogadinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new genus and three new species of parasitoid wasp from Papua New Guinea and redescription of Trigonophatnus Cameron (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Rogadinae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Vojtechirogas novotnyi
sp. nov. Gender masculine. Additional species:
V. heberti
sp. nov. ;
V. wantok
sp. nov.

caption.paragraph:
Figures 1–13. (1–12)
Vojtechirogas novotnyi
gen. nov. & sp. nov., paratype female (12 of second paratype). (13)
V. herberti
sp. nov. , holotype female. (1) Wings; (2) outer hind claw; (3, 13) head, dorsal aspect; (4) mesosoma, dorsal aspect; (5) hind leg; (6) head, anterior aspect; (7) first metasomal tergite, dorsal aspect; (8) antenna; (9) habitus, lateral aspect; (10) hind tibial spurs; (11, 12) Detail of vein 1r-m and surrounding veins of hind wing. Magnification of scale line: 1.0× for 1, 5, 8, 9; 5.0× for 2; 1.5× for 3, 4, 6, 7, 10, 13; and 2.6× for 11, 12.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Antenna longer than forewing. Terminal flagellomere strongly acuminate. Maxillary and labial palpi of female slender. Face wide. Occipital carina complete dorsally (but narrowly interrupted in
V. herberti
sp. nov. ) and ventrally; ventrally strongly and more or less perpendicularly curved to join hypostomal carina. Tarsal claws with pointed basal lobes. Dorsal carinae of first metasomal tergite remain separated and second tergite has indistinct mediobasal area. Hind wing with vein SR tubular until beyond hamuli, very strongly curved such that at most extreme it almost reaches wing margin, where there is usually a distinct inclivous fold representing cross-vein r; vein 2-SC+R swollen; vein r-m strongly curved.

Vojtechirogas
gen. nov. can be recognized from other genera of Rogadinae with a sclerotized and more or less curved vein SR1 of hind wing as follows:

1. Tarsal claws pectinate; marginal cell of hind wing strongly widened apically; second metasomal tergite finely sculptured; eyes and ocelli strongly enlarged; Afrotropical.............................
Scoporogas van Achterberg, 1991

– Tarsal claws without pecten ( Figures 2 , 22 ); marginal cell of hind wing subparallel-sided apically ( Figures 1 , 14 ); second tergite coarsely sculptured, often costate (Figures, 20); eyes and ocelli less developed ( Figures 3, 6 , 17, 21 ); Indo-Australian......................................................... 2

2. Head strongly protuberant in dorsal view; mediolongitudinal carina of propodeum present anteriorly; vein 2-SC+R of hind wing hardly widened; hind femur slender; pronotum coriaceous ventrally; marginal cell of hind wing near hamuli wider than apically; vein 1r-m of hind wing oblique and straight; Oriental...........................................
Rhogasella Baker, 1917

– Head hardly protuberant in dorsal view ( Figures 3 , 21 ); mediolongitudinal carina of propodeum absent anteriorly ( Figures 4 , 19 ); vein 2-SC+R of hind wing more or less widened ( Figures 11, 12 , 25 ); hind femur moderately robust ( Figures 5 , 18 ); pronotum smooth ventrally ( Figures 9 , 24 ); marginal cell of hind wing near hamuli narrower than apically ( Figures 1 , 14 ); vein 1r-m of hind wing slightly curved or vertical ( Figures 11, 12 , 25 )................... 3

Parasitoid mainly of
Philiris helena
( Lycaenidae ) on
Macaranga spp.

paragraph.emphasis: Key to species of the genus

paragraph.keyLead:
2. Propodeum with inverted U-shaped carina that curves posteriorly outwards from mid-anterior and spits to form a pair of curved, subtransverse carina ( Figures 26, 27 ); CO1 bases 1534, 1607, 1640, 1703, 1808 and 2000 A, A, T, A, G and A respectively................................
V. novotnyi
sp. nov.

– Propodeum with anteriorly wide A-shaped carina (with two cross-bars) that angles abruptly to form transverse carinae ( Figures 29 ); CO1 bases 1534, 1607, 1640, 1703, 1808 and 2000 G, G, C, G, A and G respectvely.
V. wantok
sp. nov.
